all_identified: ENS initiation and gut‑to‑brain propagation via autonomic circuits. Experimental systems demonstrate that α‑syn pathology in the gut wall can spread to nodose ganglia and dorsal motor nucleus (DMV) and that vagotomy blocks this transfer, indicating a vagus‑mediated route; mucosal enteroendocrine cells (EECs) can transfer α‑syn to vagal neurons, providing a plausible epithelial/mucosal source of seeds (prion‑like) that access autonomic fibers (chandra2023gutmucosalcells pages 7-10, kujawska2018whatisthe pages 9-11). Bidirectional propagation along parasympathetic and sympathetic pathways has been mapped in models and fits “body‑first” PD phenotypes; human epidemiology on vagotomy is mixed but includes cohorts with reduced PD risk after complete vagotomy (wang2021theroleof pages 17-18).

Epithelial barrier dysfunction and LPS/TLR4‑driven neuroinflammation. PD cohorts show increased intestinal permeability with elevated serum LPS‑binding protein and mucosal E. coli/oxidative stress markers, correlating with enteric α‑syn deposition. In α‑syn mice, LPS reduces tight‑junction proteins (ZO‑1, E‑cadherin), increases enteric α‑syn, and curli‑producing E. coli accelerate α‑syn accumulation with higher IL‑6/TNF in microglia, linking dysbiosis to microglial/astrocyte activation via TLR4/NF‑κB signaling (dutta2019parkinson’sdiseasethe pages 4-5, wang2021theroleof pages 17-18). Systematic animal data show gut‑targeted interventions frequently downregulate TLR4 and NF‑κB and normalize barrier proteins (panaitescu2024theeffectof pages 18-19).

Microbial metabolites acting on EECs, vagal afferents, and glia. Dysbiosis in PD typically features reduced butyrate‑producing taxa and lower colonic butyrate. SCFAs regulate epithelial tight junctions and immunometabolism (HDAC/GPCR signaling) and influence microglial states; EECs sense luminal metabolites and interface with vagal afferents, enabling metabolite‑to‑neuron signaling. P
